articles.headline: In Notification of Military Deaths, More Pain
articles.snippet: The U.S. military casualty system has failed to competently guide families through the casualty process.
articles.abstract: The U.S. military casualty system has failed to competently guide families through the casualty process.
articles.lead_paragraph: After Neil Santorello heard the news that his son, a tank commander, had been killed in Iraq, from the officer in his living room, he walked out his front door and removed the American flag from its pole. Then, in tears, he tore down the yellow ribbons from his tree.

articles.headline: House Budget Effort Dropped
articles.snippet: House Republican leaders abandoned efforts to approve a budget after they were unable to bridge differences in their party. Page A22.
articles.abstract: House Republican leaders abandoned efforts to approve a budget after they were unable to bridge differences in their party. Page A22.
articles.lead_paragraph: House Republican leaders abandoned efforts to approve a budget after they were unable to bridge differences in their party. Page A22.

articles.headline: Risky Forecast: This Time Is Different
articles.snippet: SOME bets simply should not be made, for history indicates they are extraordinarily unlikely to pay off.     One such bet is that American consumers will prove to be overextended, leaving those who lend to them in deep trouble. Half a century ago,...
articles.abstract: SOME bets simply should not be made, for history indicates they are extraordinarily unlikely to pay off.     One such bet is that American consumers will prove to be overextended, leaving those who lend to them in deep trouble. Half a century ago, credit cards were unknown to the vast majority of Americans. As their use grew, there was a lot of fretting from those who were sure that the end had to be near. They were wrong, repeatedly.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOME bets simply should not be made, for history indicates they are extraordinarily unlikely to pay off.

articles.headline: F.D.A. Plans to Intensify Oversight of Heart Devices
articles.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration plans to strengthen how it monitors critical heart devices like defibrillators by appointing outside medical experts to help it review the safety of units already on the market, a top agency official says.     The ...
articles.abstract: The Food and Drug Administration plans to strengthen how it monitors critical heart devices like defibrillators by appointing outside medical experts to help it review the safety of units already on the market, a top agency official says.     The move would be the first time the F.D.A. would have outside experts regularly advising it about the safety of medical devices being sold, said Dr. Daniel G. Schultz, director of the agency's Center for Devices and Radiological Health. Traditionally, the F.D.A. has used its advisory panels to help it decide whether to permit the sale of a new device.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration plans to strengthen how it monitors critical heart devices like defibrillators by appointing outside medical experts to help it review the safety of units already on the market, a top agency official says.

articles.headline: Cheney's Aide Says President Approved Leak
articles.snippet: Vice President Dick Cheney's former chief of staff testified that he was authorized by President Bush, through Mr. Cheney, in July 2003 to disclose key parts of what until then was a classified prewar intelligence estimate on Iraq, according to a ...
articles.abstract: Vice President Dick Cheney's former chief of staff testified that he was authorized by President Bush, through Mr. Cheney, in July 2003 to disclose key parts of what until then was a classified prewar intelligence estimate on Iraq, according to a new court filing.     The testimony by the former official, I. Lewis Libby Jr., cited in a court filing by the government made late Wednesday, provides an indication that Mr. Bush, who has long criticized leaks of secret information as a threat to national security, may have played a direct role in authorizing disclosure of the intelligence report on Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 6 - Vice President Dick Cheney's former chief of staff testified that he was authorized by President Bush, through Mr. Cheney, in July 2003 to disclose key parts of what until then was a classified prewar intelligence estimate on Iraq, according to a new court filing.
articles.byline: By David Johnston and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Senate Deal on Immigration Falters
articles.snippet: Senate leaders reached agreement Thursday on a broad, bipartisan compromise that would put the vast majority of the nation's estimated 11 million illegal immigrants on a path to citizenship, but its prospects for passage grew more uncertain as Rep...
articles.abstract: Senate leaders reached agreement Thursday on a broad, bipartisan compromise that would put the vast majority of the nation's estimated 11 million illegal immigrants on a path to citizenship, but its prospects for passage grew more uncertain as Republicans and Democrats clashed late into the night over parliamentary procedure.     Both sides said that without a quick resolution of the differences they would not have a vote on the final legislation before Congress leaves for its spring recess on Friday, raising the possibility that the painstakingly negotiated compromise might unravel as it is exposed to intense political scrutiny during the two-week Congressional break.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 6 - Senate leaders reached agreement Thursday on a broad, bipartisan compromise that would put the vast majority of the nation's estimated 11 million illegal immigrants on a path to citizenship, but its prospects for passage grew more uncertain as Republicans and Democrats clashed late into the night over parliamentary procedure.

articles.headline: Bold Goal Confronts Fine Print
articles.snippet: The new Massachusetts plan to achieve nearly universal health coverage represents an important bipartisan political milestone -- one that people in many other states hope will serve as a model solution for the thorny national problem of the uninsu...
articles.abstract: The new Massachusetts plan to achieve nearly universal health coverage represents an important bipartisan political milestone -- one that people in many other states hope will serve as a model solution for the thorny national problem of the uninsured.      But policy analysts and state officials say Massachusetts now faces an even greater challenge: creating a viable market in affordable insurance policies, so that businesses and individuals will buy the coverage mandated by the bill the state's legislature passed on Tuesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: The new Massachusetts plan to achieve nearly universal health coverage represents an important bipartisan political milestone -- one that people in many other states hope will serve as a model solution for the thorny national problem of the uninsured.

articles.headline: In Ancient Document, Judas, Minus the Betrayal
articles.snippet: An early Christian manuscript, including the only known text of the Gospel of Judas, has surfaced after 1,700 years, and it portrays Judas Iscariot not as a betrayer of Jesus but as his favored disciple and willing collaborator.     In this text, ...
articles.abstract: An early Christian manuscript, including the only known text of the Gospel of Judas, has surfaced after 1,700 years, and it portrays Judas Iscariot not as a betrayer of Jesus but as his favored disciple and willing collaborator.     In this text, scholars reported yesterday, the account of events leading to the Crucifixion differs sharply from the four gospels in the New Testament. Here Jesus is said to entrust Judas with special knowledge and ask him to betray him to the Roman authorities. By doing so, he tells Judas, ''you will exceed'' the other disciples.
articles.lead_paragraph: An early Christian manuscript, including the only known text of the Gospel of Judas, has surfaced after 1,700 years, and it portrays Judas Iscariot not as a betrayer of Jesus but as his favored disciple and willing collaborator.
articles.byline: By John Noble Wilford and Laurie Goodstein

articles.headline: In Notification of Military Deaths, More Pain
articles.snippet: After Neil Santorello heard the news that his son, a tank commander, had been killed in Iraq, from the officer in his living room, he walked out his front door and removed the American flag from its pole. Then, in tears, he tore down the yellow ri...
articles.abstract: After Neil Santorello heard the news that his son, a tank commander, had been killed in Iraq, from the officer in his living room, he walked out his front door and removed the American flag from its pole. Then, in tears, he tore down the yellow ribbons from his tree.     Rather than see it as the act of a man unmoored by the death of his 24-year-old son, the officer, an Army major, confronted Mr. Santorello, saying,
articles.lead_paragraph: After Neil Santorello heard the news that his son, a tank commander, had been killed in Iraq, from the officer in his living room, he walked out his front door and removed the American flag from its pole. Then, in tears, he tore down the yellow ribbons from his tree.

articles.headline: Is Paulson Going Public?
articles.snippet: Each day as Henry M. Paulson Jr. walks down the lushly carpeted hall to his 30th-floor executive suite at the Goldman Sachs headquarters in Lower Manhattan, he is reminded of the firm's tradition of sending its best and brightest to Washington.   ...
articles.abstract: Each day as Henry M. Paulson Jr. walks down the lushly carpeted hall to his 30th-floor executive suite at the Goldman Sachs headquarters in Lower Manhattan, he is reminded of the firm's tradition of sending its best and brightest to Washington.      On the walls are oil portraits of his predecessors: John C. Whitehead, Robert E. Rubin and Stephen Friedman, all of whom left the firm for careers in government. (His most recent predecessor, Jon S. Corzine, now governor of New Jersey, has yet to sit for his painting.)
articles.lead_paragraph: Each day as Henry M. Paulson Jr. walks down the lushly carpeted hall to his 30th-floor executive suite at the Goldman Sachs headquarters in Lower Manhattan, he is reminded of the firm's tradition of sending its best and brightest to Washington.

articles.headline: Couric Says Jump, and Fans Reach for Their Remotes
articles.snippet: Three nights a week, Ann Viele usually sits down to watch at least part of the evening news, and when she does, she chooses the newscast of Brian Williams on NBC, just as she did Tom Brokaw's before him.     But Thursday morning, as she sweated th...
articles.abstract: Three nights a week, Ann Viele usually sits down to watch at least part of the evening news, and when she does, she chooses the newscast of Brian Williams on NBC, just as she did Tom Brokaw's before him.     But Thursday morning, as she sweated through a workout on an elliptical machine at the downtown Y.M.C.A., she gestured toward the small screen in front of her -- it displayed Katie Couric on the ''Today'' show -- and made a pledge: Come fall, when Ms. Couric jumps from ''Today'' to the ''CBS Evening News,'' Ms. Viele plans to jump with her.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., April 6 - Three nights a week, Ann Viele usually sits down to watch at least part of the evening news, and when she does, she chooses the newscast of Brian Williams on NBC, just as she did Tom Brokaw's before him.
